These docs are in Beta and actively updated daily. Please report if you find any issues.
This guide walks you through creating your account and registering your first subdomain on Stackryze Domains.
Currently offering: indevs.in subdomains. More domains coming soon!
Click the "Get Started" button on the landing page

l: Option A: Sign up with Email (Recommended)
p: Enter your Name, Email, and a secure Password.
You will see a verification screen. Check your email for a 6-digit code.
Enter the code to verify your account.
Didn't receive the code? Click the "Resend" button on the verification page to get a new code.

New GitHub registrations are currently paused. To use GitHub login, you must first create an account with Email/Password(using the same email address as your GitHub account). Once registered, you can link your GitHub account by logging in with it.
If you already have an account:
To keep your account secure, we have implemented the following protections:
Email Verification: Required for all new accounts.
Account Lockout: After 5 failed login attempts, your account will be locked for 30 minutes. This prevents brute-force attacks.
Note on Passwords: If you set a password, ensure it is strong (min 8 characters).
After logging in, click "Register Domain" from the sidebar menu
Now fill out the registration form:
Type your desired subdomain name in the input field.
Characters: Lowercase letters, numbers, and hyphens only
Format: Cannot start or end with a hyphen
The system automatically checks availability as you type:
🔴 Red X- Domain is taken or invalid
Check the box to accept the Terms of Service and Privacy Policy
Complete the hCaptcha verification to prove you're human
Click the "Register Domain" button to complete registration
Congratulations! Your domain is now registered and active.
View your domain in My Domains
Set up DNS records with your DNS provider
Learn how to manage your domain (renew, update nameservers, delete)
You can register up to 5 domains by default. Domain names must be 3-63 characters long.
If you encounter any problems during registration:
🔧 Troubleshooting Guide- Solutions for common login and registration errors
💬 Discord Community- Live help (Faster than email!)
📧 Email Support- Contact us for help
Now that you've registered your domain:
Set up DNS- Configure your DNS provider
Manage your domain- Update nameservers, renew, or delete
Ready to get started? Visit domain.stackryze.com and register your first domain today!
These docs are in Beta and actively updated daily. Please report if you find any issues.
Learn how to manage your registered domains, update nameservers, renew, and delete domains.
You'll see all your registered domains with their current status, expiry date, and nameservers.
Status- Active, Expiring Soon, or Expired
Registered On- When you registered the domain
Expiry Date- When the domain expires
Registration Period- Current validity period (1 Year Fixed)
Set up your DNS provider first:
Click the "Manage" button for your domain
In the DNS Configuration section, click "Edit"
Replace the default nameservers ( ns1.stackryze.com, ns2.stackryze.com) with your new ones:
DNS changes propagate in 5-10 minutes but can take up to 48 hours globally.
Domains are valid for 1 year from registration.
Find your domain in the list
Click the "Renew" button (green button on the right)
Renewal is 100% free! There's no cost to extend your domain.
If you click "Renew" before the 60-day window, you'll see a message showing how many days until renewal is available.
Grace period - domain still works, DNS remains active
Domain is soft-deleted, DNS records removed
Cooling-off period (7 days) - name cannot be registered by anyone
Name becomes available for registration again
You can only renew the domain during the 15-day grace period.
Once the grace period ends (Day 15), the domain is deleted and cannot be renewed.
If you no longer need a domain, you can delete it from the Danger Zone.
Scroll to the "Danger Zone" section at the bottom
DNS records are removed immediately. Your domain will stop working right away.
Name cannot be registered by you or others during this time
Deletion is permanent- domains cannot be restored once deleted
Once you delete a domain, it enters a 7-day cooling-off period. After 7 days, the name becomes available for anyone to register. Restoration is not possible.
Domain has expired but is in grace period (1-15 days)
Removed from DNS (Cooling off for 7 days)
waiting for DNS records to be created (automatic retry)
Track all changes to your domains:
We'll review and respond within 1-2 business days.
Verify nameservers are correct in dashboard
Check DNS records in your DNS provider
Ensure DNS zone is configured correctly
Wait up to 48 hours for global propagation
You can only renew 60 days before expiry
If expired, check if it's in the 15-day grace period
Wait for the 7-day cooling-off period to complete
Re-register the domain once it becomes available
Note: Deletions are permanent and cannot be undone by support.
Set calendar reminders for renewal (60 days before expiry)
Keep your email updated for notifications
Monitor activity history for unauthorized changes
Use a reliable DNS provider (Cloudflare recommended)
Configure proper DNS records (A, CNAME, MX, TXT)
Test your domain after any changes

These docs are in Beta and actively updated daily. Please report if you find any issues.
Having issues? This guide covers common problems and their solutions.
Error: Your GitHub account must be at least 7 days old
Wait until your GitHub account is 7 days old
This is a security measure to prevent spam and abuse
Contact support@stackryze.com if you believe this is an error
Error: Your GitHub account doesn't have a public email address
Or add a public email to your profile
Error: Your account has been banned for violating terms of service
Contact support@stackryze.com if you think this is a mistake
Include your GitHub username in the email
Note: Banned accounts are immediately logged out on all devices.
Error: New registrations are temporarily disabled
This is rare and usually temporary
Check our status page for updates
Try again later or contact support
Clear your browser cookies and cache
Check if GitHub is down: GitHub Status
Contact support@stackryze.com if the issue persists

l: "Domain name must be at least 3 characters"
p: Error: Your subdomain is too short

l: "Domain name must be less than 63 characters"
p: Error: Your subdomain is too long
Use a shorter, more memorable name

l: "Domain name can only contain lowercase letters, numbers, and hyphens"
p: Error: Invalid characters in subdomain name
No uppercase letters, spaces, or special characters
Cannot start or end with a hyphen
Error: Someone else has already registered this name
Add numbers or hyphens: myproject2, my-project
Check if it's available first (green checkmark)

l: "This name is in a cooling-off period"
p: Error: Domain was recently deleted and is in a 7-day waiting period
The error message shows how many days remaining
Error: You've registered the maximum number of domains (default: 5)
Email support@stackryze.com to request a limit increase
Include your GitHub username and reason for increase
Error: You didn't provide enough nameservers
Most DNS providers give you 2-4 nameservers
Error: Nameserver doesn't match valid DNS hostname format
Error: You entered the same nameserver multiple times
Error: hCaptcha verification didn't complete successfully
Make sure you're not using a VPN or proxy
Problem: DNS still points to old nameservers
Verify nameservers are correct in dashboard
Problem: Domain doesn't load or shows DNS errors
Verify nameservers are correctly set in dashboard
Check DNS records in your DNS provider (Cloudflare, Route53, etc.)
Ensure your DNS provider zone is configured for your subdomain
Wait up to 48 hours for global DNS propagation
Test with: dig yourname.indevs.in or nslookup yourname.indevs.in
Problem: Browser shows "Not Secure" or SSL errors
Configure SSL in your DNS provider (e.g., Cloudflare)
Wait up to 24 hours for certificate provisioning
Ensure your origin server supports HTTPS
Check SSL mode settings in your DNS provider
Verify DNS records point to the correct server
You can only renew 60 days before expiry
If expired, check if it's in the 15-day grace period
Contact support@stackryze.com if you need help
Deletion is permanent and cannot be undone.
You must wait for the 7-day cooling-off period to complete.
After 7 days, the name becomes available for registration again.
You will need to re-register the domain.
Support cannot restore deleted domains. Please be careful when using the Danger Zone.

l: Domain shows as expired but I renewed it
p: Problem: Status not updating after renewal
Log out and log back in
Wait a few minutes for the database to update
Contact support if the issue persists
Check if the service is down: Status Page
Check if your browser is blocking third-party cookies
Clear cookies and log in again
Problem: Updates to nameservers or settings not saving
Check for error messages on screen
Ensure all required fields are filled
Try again in a few minutes
Contact support with details of what you're trying to change
Error: You've exceeded the rate limit for a specific action
Domain availability checks: 20 checks per minute
Wait for the specified time period (shown in error message)
Don't use automated scripts or bots
The error message shows when you can try again
Rate limits are per IP address and reset automatically after the time window.
Problem: Your site works, but Uptime Kuma or other monitoring tools show it as "Down" (403 Forbidden or 503 Service Unavailable).
Cause: Cloudflare's "Under Attack Mode" or "JavaScript Challenge" blocks automated bots, including monitoring tools.
Solution: Create a WAF Exception Rule for your monitor.
Go to Cloudflare Dashboard→ Security→ WAF
Checkbox: Select All remaining custom rules and WAF Managed Rules(or specifically "Super Bot Fight Mode" if available)
💬 Discord Community: Join for live help
If your issue isn't listed here or the solutions don't work:
Response Time: We typically respond to support emails within 24-48 hours on business days.
These docs are in Beta and actively updated daily. Please report if you find any issues.
Quick answers to common questions. For detailed guides, see the links below.

l: How long is my domain valid?
p: Domains are valid for 1 year from registration. You can renew 60 days before expiry.
No! Stackryze Domains is 100% free with no hidden fees.

l: How many domains can I register?
p: 5 domains by default. Need more? Email support@stackryze.com.

l: Can I change my subdomain name after registration?
p: No. Subdomain names cannot be changed. You must delete and register a new one.

l: What if I make a mistake during registration?
p: Delete your domain within 15 days and register again. The name will be available after a 7-day cooling-off period.

l: Why was my domain registration rejected?
p: Common reasons: name too short/long, invalid characters, already taken, or in cooling-off period.
Nameservers tell the internet where to find your domain. Default: ns1.stackryze.com and ns2.stackryze.com.

l: Can I use my own DNS provider?
p: Yes! Use Cloudflare, AWS Route 53, Google Cloud DNS, or any other provider.

l: How long does DNS propagation take?
p: Typically 5-10 minutes, but can take up to 48 hours globally.

l: How do I renew my domain?
p: Go to My Domains, click "Renew", confirm. It's free!

l: What happens if my domain expires?
How do I delete a domain?
p: Go to domain management page → "Danger Zone" → "Delete Domain". DNS is removed immediately.

l: Can I restore a deleted domain?
p: No. Once a domain is deleted, it enters a 7-day cooling-off period. After this period, you (or anyone else) can register it again as a new domain.

l: Why do I need a GitHub account?
p: We use GitHub OAuth for secure authentication. It prevents spam and ensures accountability.

l: Can I use a new GitHub account?
p: Your GitHub account must be at least 7 days old. This prevents spam.

l: How do I change my email address?
p: Your email is linked to GitHub. Update it in your GitHub settings.
Check nameservers, DNS records, and wait up to 48 hours for propagation.
Renewal opens 60 days before expiry. Check your expiry date.
Deletion is permanent. You must wait for the 7-day cooling-off period to re-register the domain.

l: How long does support take to respond?

Stackryze Domains uses a Bring Your Own DNS (BYOD) approach, giving you complete control over your subdomain's DNS configuration. You can use any DNS provider that offers nameserver delegation.
Currently offering: indevs.in subdomains. More domains coming soon!
This page lists popular DNS providers that work well with Stackryze Domains, along with setup guides for each.
Free Tier: Yes Features: Fast global network, DDoS protection, free SSL, analytics Best For: Most users, beginners to advanced
Free Tier: Limited (first 12 months) Features: Highly reliable, integrates with AWS services, health checks Best For: AWS users, enterprise applications
Free Tier: Limited Features: Low latency, integrates with GCP, DNSSEC support Best For: Google Cloud users, high-traffic applications
Free Tier: Limited Features: Integrates with Azure, high availability Best For: Microsoft Azure users
Free Tier: Yes (with DigitalOcean account) Features: Simple interface, free with any DigitalOcean service Best For: DigitalOcean users, simple setups
Free Tier: Yes Features: Free DNS hosting, simple API, reliable infrastructure Best For: Hetzner customers, European users
Free Tier: Yes Features: Free DNS hosting, multiple record types, API access Best For: Budget-conscious users, small projects
Free Tier: Yes Features: Completely free, IPv6 support, DNSSEC Best For: Advanced users, IPv6 enthusiasts
Free Tier: Yes Features: Free DNS hosting, easy to use Best For: Namecheap customers, simple projects
Free Tier: Yes (with Vercel account) Features: Automatic SSL, edge network, simple setup Best For: Vercel users, frontend developers
Free Tier: Yes Features: Free DNSSEC-enabled DNS, privacy-focused, open source Best For: Privacy-conscious users, DNSSEC requirements
Free Tier: Yes (open source) Features: Self-hosted, API-driven, highly customizable Best For: Advanced users, custom infrastructure
AWS Route 53 is ideal if you're already using AWS services for seamless integration.
Hurricane Electric or Cloudns offer completely free DNS hosting with no hidden costs.
AWS Route 53, Google Cloud DNS, or Azure DNS provide enterprise-grade reliability and SLA guarantees.
All DNS providers must meet these requirements to work with Stackryze Domains:
Nameserver Support: Must provide authoritative nameservers
Zone Management: Ability to create and manage DNS zones
Public Accessibility: Nameservers must be publicly accessible
Standard Records: Support for A, AAAA, CNAME, TXT, MX, and other standard DNS records
Your DNS provider should allow you to create a zone for your subdomain (e.g., yourname.indevs.in) and provide at least 2 nameservers.
If you're unsure which DNS provider to choose, check our FAQ, join our Discord Community, or contact us at support@stackryze.com.
Know a great DNS provider that should be listed here? Submit a pull request or open an issue.
These docs are in Beta and actively updated daily. Please report if you find any issues.

l: Cloudflare DNS Setup for Stackryze Domains
p: These docs are in Beta and actively updated daily. Please report if you find any issues.
This guide shows you how to use Cloudflare as your DNS provider for your Stackryze Domains subdomain.
Free Forever: No cost for DNS hosting
Fast Global Network: 300+ data centers worldwide
Free SSL: Automatic HTTPS for your subdomain
If you haven't registered your subdomain yet, see our Getting Started guide first.

l: Step 1: Add Your Subdomain to Cloudflare
p: Log in to your Cloudflare dashboard
Enter your complete subdomain (e.g., myproject.indevs.in), not just the base domain.
The Free plan includes everything you need for DNS hosting. You can upgrade later if needed.
Cloudflare will assign unique nameservers to your domain:
Look for the nameserver information on screen
Copy both nameservers- you'll need them in the next step
Your nameservers will be different from this example. Copy the exact ones Cloudflare assigns to you.
Go to DNS→ Records in Cloudflare
Scroll to the Cloudflare Nameservers section

l: Step 4: Update Nameservers in Stackryze Domains
p: Now update your domain to use Cloudflare:
Replace the nameservers with your Cloudflare ones:
DNS changes typically propagate in 5-10 minutes, but can take up to 48 hours globally.
Return to your Cloudflare dashboard Overview page.
Click "Check nameservers now" to initiate a check.
Cloudflare will verify your nameservers. This usually takes a few minutes but can take up to 24 hours.
Email Confirmation: Cloudflare will send you an email confirmation once your site is active.
When successful, you will see a confirmation message:
Access DNS Records 2. Click "Add record" 3. Configure your records based on your needs:
Example: Point to an IP Address
In Cloudflare, go to DNS→ Records
Now add your DNS records in Cloudflare:
Set SSL mode to Full or Full (strict)
SSL certificates are automatically provisioned. This can take up to 24 hours.

l: Proxy Status (Orange Cloud vs Gray Cloud)
p: May cause issues with some services
Start with gray cloud (DNS only) until your domain is working, then experiment with proxying if needed.
Solution: Wait a few minutes after adding your site. Cloudflare needs to provision nameservers.
Verify nameservers are correctly updated in your Stackryze dashboard
Ensure your origin server supports HTTPS
Set SSL mode to Flexible if your origin doesn't have SSL
Wait up to 24 hours for certificate provisioning
Verify nameservers in Stackryze dashboard match Cloudflare
Wait up to 48 hours for full propagation

If you prefer to run your own DNS infrastructure, you can use custom DNS servers with indevs Domains. This guide covers the requirements and setup process.
Your custom DNS servers must meet these requirements:
Publicly Accessible: Nameservers must be reachable from the internet
Authoritative: Must be configured as authoritative nameservers for your subdomain
Reliable: Should have good uptime (99%+ recommended)
Standard Compliant: Must follow DNS RFC standards
Multiple Servers: At least 2 nameservers recommended for redundancy
Platform: Linux, BSD, Windows Difficulty: Advanced Best For: Enterprise setups, experienced administrators
Platform: Linux, BSD Difficulty: Intermediate to Advanced Best For: Modern setups, API-driven management
Platform: Linux, BSD Difficulty: Intermediate Best For: Authoritative-only DNS, security-focused setups
Platform: Linux, BSD Difficulty: Intermediate Best For: High-performance setups, DNSSEC
Choose and install your preferred DNS server software on your server(s).
Create a zone file for your indevs subdomain:
Before registering with indevs, test your DNS servers:
Always configure at least 2 nameservers for redundancy:
Place nameservers in different geographic locations for better reliability and performance.
Use monitoring tools to ensure your nameservers are always available:
Regularly update your DNS server software to patch security vulnerabilities.
For enhanced security, consider enabling DNSSEC on your nameservers.
Verify zone is properly loaded in configuration
Only allow zone transfers to authorized secondary nameservers:
Implement rate limiting to prevent DNS amplification attacks.
Restrict who can update DNS records using:

Advanced Setup - Not Recommended for Beginners

PowerDNS is a complex, self-hosted DNS solution that requires significant technical expertise in server administration, DNS protocols, and database management. This setup is recommended only for experienced system administrators who understand DNS internals, security hardening, and high-availability infrastructure.

PowerDNS Authoritative Server is a versatile, open-source nameserver that supports multiple backends for storing DNS records. Stackryze uses PowerDNS to power ns1.stackryze.com and ns2.stackryze.com, which manage all indevs.in subdomains.
Complete Control: Full ownership of your DNS infrastructure
Multiple Backends: PostgreSQL, SQLite, BIND zone files, and more
RESTful HTTP API: Programmatic DNS management
High Performance: Designed to handle millions of queries
DNSSEC Support: Built-in support for DNS security extensions
Active Development: Regular updates and security patches
Before you begin, ensure you have:
✅ Linux Server(s): VPS or dedicated server with root access (minimum 2 servers recommended for redundancy)
✅ Public Static IP(s): At least one static public IP address
✅ DNS Knowledge: Understanding of DNS zones, records, and nameserver delegation
✅ Database Knowledge: Familiarity with PostgreSQL (if using database backend)
For production use, you need at least 2 nameservers for redundancy. This guide covers a single-server setup for learning purposes.
Caching resolver (not needed for this guide)
For this guide, we'll use powerdns/pdns-auth-49 as it's the latest stable authoritative server needed for subdomain delegation.
PowerDNS provides official Docker images at hub.docker.com/u/powerdns:
PostgreSQL is an excellent production database backend for PowerDNS, offering robust performance, standards compliance, and advanced features.
Create schema-postgres.sql with the official PowerDNS 4.7+ PostgreSQL schema:
Allow DNS traffic on your server:
Security Critical: Never expose port 8081 (API) to the public internet without authentication and IP restrictions. Use a VPN, SSH tunnel, or firewall rules to restrict access.
PowerDNS provides a RESTful HTTP API for managing zones and records.
Zone names MUST end with a dot (.). For example: yourname.indevs.in.
Once your PowerDNS server is running and configured:
Nameserver 1: n1.yourdomain.com(must have an A record pointing to your server IP)
Nameserver 2: n2.yourdomain.com(for redundancy, pointing to secondary server)
Your nameserver hostnames ( n1.yourdomain.com) must have A records in their parent zone pointing to your PowerDNS server IPs. Contact your domain registrar to set up glue records if needed.
DNS Checker- Check global DNS propagation
What's My DNS- Worldwide DNS propagation checker

l: High Availability Setup with Master-Slave Replication
p: For production DNS infrastructure, you need at least 2 nameservers for redundancy and reliability. PowerDNS supports master-slave replication using AXFR (Authoritative Zone Transfer).
AXFR(Authoritative Transfer) is a DNS protocol mechanism that allows a secondary (slave) nameserver to request a complete copy of a DNS zone from a primary (master) nameserver.
Master Server(n1) holds the authoritative DNS data
Slave Server(n2) periodically requests zone updates from the master
Zone data is transferred via AXFR protocol over TCP port 53
Slave automatically stays synchronized with master changes
Redundancy: If master fails, slave continues serving DNS
Load Distribution: Both servers can answer queries
Geographic Distribution: Place servers in different locations for better performance
Automatic Synchronization: Slave automatically gets updates from master
ns1.stackryze.com- Master (Primary)- Receives all DNS updates via API
ns2.stackryze.com- Slave (Secondary)- Replicates from n1 via AXFR
When a user updates their nameservers through the Stackryze platform, the API updates n1 (master), and n2 (slave) automatically receives the changes via AXFR zone transfer.
The master server is where all DNS changes are made (via API or manual edits).
Replace SLAVE_SERVER_IP with your secondary server's IP address (e.g., 203.0.113.2)
The slave server automatically replicates zones from the master via AXFR.
On the slave server, add the master as a supermaster:
Replace MASTER_SERVER_IP with your master server's IP.
When you create a zone on the master, set the type to Master:
Check if the zone exists on the slave:
Admin makes DNS change on master(n1) via API
Master increments the zone's SOA serial number
Slave requests AXFR(full zone transfer) from master
Master transfers complete zone data to slave
Both servers now serve identical DNS data
Verify allow-axfr-ips on master includes slave IP
Check firewall allows TCP port 53 from slave to master
Verify slave IP is correct in master configuration
Only allow API access from trusted IPs:
Generate a cryptographically secure API key:
Query logging can impact performance and fill disk space.
Problem: Another service (like systemd-resolved) is using port 53.
Problem: PowerDNS can't connect to PostgreSQL.
Verify database container is running: docker-compose ps
Check credentials match in both docker-compose.yml and pdns.conf
Wait 30-60 seconds after starting database before starting PowerDNS
Check database logs: docker-compose logs postgres
Problem: Nameserver doesn't respond to queries.
Problem: API key is incorrect or not configured.
Verify X-API-Key header matches the key in pdns.conf
Ensure api=yes is set in configuration
Restart PowerDNS after config changes: docker-compose restart powerdns
Check if API is enabled: curl http://localhost:8081/api
Problem: Zone exists but queries fail.
If PowerDNS seems too complex for your needs, consider these easier alternatives:
Cloudflare- Free, easy to use, highly recommended for beginners
Hurricane Electric- Free DNS hosting with simple interface
deSEC- Free, privacy-focused DNS with API
ClouDNS- Free tier with good features
Stackryze uses PowerDNS to power our authoritative nameservers:
ns1.stackryze.com(Primary) - PowerDNS Authoritative Server with PostgreSQL backend
ns2.stackryze.com(Secondary) - PowerDNS Authoritative Server with PostgreSQL replication
These servers manage DNS delegation for all indevs.in subdomains through PowerDNS's HTTP API, allowing automated zone creation and record management when users register domains through our platform.
Need help? Join our Discord or contact support@stackryze.com

For Beginners: We strongly recommend starting with Cloudflare instead of self-hosting with PowerDNS. Self-hosting DNS requires significant expertise in system administration, security, and DNS protocols.
